"I think that my darkest moment was the Iraq war, and the fact that we could not stop it. I worked very hard ‚Äî I was working the phone, talking to leaders around the world.

‚Ä¢
But I think the council was right in not sanctioning the war. Could you imagine if the U.N. had endorsed the war in Iraq, what our reputation would be like? Although at that point, President (George W.) Bush said the U.N. was headed toward irrelevance, because we had not supported the war. But now we know better." ~former United Nations Secretary General and Nobel Peace Prize winner Kofi Annan (b. 1938-d. 2018)

With Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy retiring, Donald Trump is positioned to shift the court to the right for a generation to come.

But back in 2016, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell refused to allow hearings for President Obama's Supreme Court nominee Merrick Garland because it was an election year. The seat was left vacant until 2017. **Following the McConnell Rule, the Senate shouldn't confirm a successor for Kennedy until 2019.** McConnell set the new standard by giving the voters a say in the upcoming elections before vacancies are filled. 
The Senate should be consistent. The confirmation proceedings should be postponed until the new Congress is seated in January 2019.

Kennedy, a Republican, often served a critical swing vote on issues such as abortion and affirmative action. We cannot allow another of Trump's extremist nominees to wildly undo decades of civil rights, one majority opinion at a time. 
Take action and tell your senators: Follow the McConnell Rule. No Supreme Court confirmations during an election year.  link in bio. (üì∏ Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

On this day in 2007, writer KURT VONNEGUT died, at the age of 84.
‚Ä¢
Despite always wanting to be a writer, Vonnegut was pushed by his family to study something useful‚Äìso he studied biochemistry at Cornell, while working at the school newspaper. Later, during WWII, the US military trained the pacifist in mechanical engineering.
‚Ä¢
After fighting in the Battle of the Bulge, Vonnegut, along with 50 other Allied soldiers, was taken captive and moved to Dresden. As a POW, he survived a brutal Allied attack on the city by hiding in an underground meat locker.
‚Ä¢
After the war, Vonnegut married his childhood sweetheart and they both enrolled at the University of Chicago; neither would graduate, but they did go on to have three children of their own, in addition to adopting Vonnegut's three nephews after his sister's death. Vonnegut and his wife would later part amicably; he had another child with his second wife.
‚Ä¢
Vonnegut's writing career grew slowly. While working as a reporter, and then a publicist, he began selling short stories on the side. When he decided to write full-time in 1951, he had no idea it would be 18 years before his first commercial success, SLAUGHTERHOUSE FIVE, would be published.
‚Ä¢
Though he never managed to achieve the same runaway success of SLAUGHTERHOUSE, Vonnegut continued to write, teach, and speak his mind until his death. All in all, Vonnegut published fourteen novels, three short story collections, five plays and five non-fiction books.

Since he was born a slave, BOOKER T. WASHINGTON‚Äôs true birthdate will never be proven; however, April 5, 1856 is the date most commonly recognized as his birthday.
‚Ä¢
After the Civil War, Booker and his mother moved from Virginia to West Virginia. Washington found work with his stepfather in the salt furnaces, and went to school part time, thanks to the support of a white employer who saw his potential.
‚Ä¢
At 16, Washington began studies at what is now Hampton University, again with the help of a white benefactor. By 1879, he was teaching there, and by 1881, he was tapped to found what‚Äôs now known as Tuskegee University, serving as University President until his death in 1915.
‚Ä¢
Despite his undeniable contributions to the education of African Americans, Washington‚Äôs public outlook and prescriptions for how to achieve equality varied quite a bit from the tactics of blacks born free in the North...and his private revolutionary activities often contradicted his public ones. Washington‚Äôs approach caused division among other black activists, including W.E.B. Du Bois, and led to the snarky nickname ‚ÄòThe Great Accomodator.‚Äô Meanwhile, white people were surprised to discover that black people considered Washington a sellout. But was he?
‚Ä¢
In the words of the New Yorker‚Äôs Kelefa Sanneh:
‚Ä¢
‚ÄúHe claimed that the racial problems of America, and particularly of the South, would slowly work themselves out, but he also claimed that there would be hell to pay if anyone tried to hurry that process along. Although his optimism was discredited in his own lifetime, his pessimism still reverberates.‚Äù #bookertwashington #education #history #blackhistory #americanhistory #virginia #westvirginia #hamptonuniversity #tuskegeeuniversity #education #activism #equality #equalrights #civilrights #historicalfigures #learnsomething #quotes #throwbackthursday #tbt #happybirthday #hbd #restinpeace #restinpower

"Marsha P. Johnson was an activist, a sex worker, a drag performer and, for nearly three decades, a fixture of street life in Greenwich Village.
She was a central figure in a gay liberation movement energized by the 1969 police raid on the Stonewall Inn.
She was a model for Andy Warhol.
She battled severe mental illness.
She was usually destitute and, for much of her life, effectively homeless.

When she died at 46, under murky circumstances, in summer 1992, Johnson was mourned by her many friends, but her death did not attract much notice in the mainstream press.

In the years since, however, interest in her legacy has soared. She has been praised for her insistent calls for social and economic justice; for working on behalf of homeless street youth ostracized by their families for being gay or otherwise not conforming to traditional ideas about gender; and, later, for her advocacy on behalf of AIDS patients.

Some have called her a saint." #WomensHistory #WomensHistoryMonth #LGBTQHistory #TransHistory #Stonewall #SaintMarsha #Icon #Hero #Shero #LGBTQRights #Equality #GayRights #GreenwichVillage #1960s #1970s #HIVpositive #Mysteries #Legendary #transgenderpride #liveauthentically #gender #QuoteOfTheDay #fiercewomen #fightforjustice

Born and raised in Lorain, Ohio, TONI MORRISON published her first book, The Bluest Eye, in 1970, at the age of 39, after working nearly a decade as an English professor, and then becoming the first black woman to work as a senior editor at Random House. where she lifted up black writers who may have never seen the light of day without her championing their work. Her work spans fiction, nonfiction, and even opera, and has never hesitated to explore the experiences of black women in a world that does not value them.

LADY ADA BYRON LOVELACE recognized the limitless potential of a computer long before the digital age. A computer could be programmed to follow instructions, she stated in 1843. It could also create, weaving ‚Äúalgebraic patterns just as the Jacquard loom weaves flowers and leaves.‚Äù
-üçÉüñ•üçÉ-
The computer she wrote about was never built. But it was her deep understanding of the potential for computers to change the world that earned Lovelace a place in history books as the first computer programmer.
-ü§©ü§©ü§©-
Lovelace was the daughter of poet Lord Byron, and bucked tradition by choosing to be a mathematician rather than embrace life as a socialite. She died of uterine cancer in 1852. She was just 36 years old.¬†Her work was rediscovered in the mid-1900s, and she now has a programming language named for her. Every October, we celebrate Ada Lovelace Day to honor women in technology around the world.

Humans have been using coffee beans to make drinks for at least a thousand years, but it wasn‚Äôt until the the turn of the 20th century that the coffee that fuels so many of us today got a major update and improvement‚Ä¶at the hands of MELITTA BENTZ, a German homemaker and inventor.
-
‚òïÔ∏è‚òïÔ∏è‚òïÔ∏è
- 
In Bentz‚Äôs day, the usual brewing method was to bundle coffee grounds in a small cloth bag and place the bag into a pot of boiling water; the drink created was bitter and gritty. Bentz wasn‚Äôt satisfied: using thick paper and a brass pot, she trapped the grounds, creating a smooth, delicious beverage that billions of people around the world still consume today.
-
‚òïÔ∏è‚òïÔ∏è‚òïÔ∏è
- 
Bentz patented her brewing system in 1908, and founded a business that still bears her name, Melitta, over a century later.

"I announce myself as candidate for the presidency," Victoria Claflin Woodhull said in 1872. "I anticipate criticism; but however unfavorable I trust that my sincerity will not be called into question."
-üá∫üá∏üá∫üá∏üá∫üá∏-
Like Hillary Clinton, Victoria Woodhull's enemies relied on gendered insults to attack her during her campaign. The press referred to her as a "witch;" political cartoons called her "Mrs. Satan."
-üòàüëøüòà-
When Woodhull ran, she was only 34, one year too young to be U.S. president. She also was arrested for publishing "scandalous" material just three days before the vote, spending Election Day in a New York City Jail. Women also weren't allowed to vote yet...so even if she had not been behind bars, she couldn't have voted for herself...and neither could the women who supported her campaign. It's not known exactly how many votes she received, but estimates indicate that it couldn't have been more than a few thousand...and she was never a threat to incumbent Ulysses S. Grant.

"Emancipate yourselves from mental slavery; none but ourselves can free our minds." ~Bob Marley, "Redemption Song" üé∂üé∂üé∂üé∂üé∂
*
February 1945: Nesta Robert Marley was born in rural St. Ann Parish, Jamaica, before moving to the Trench Town neighborhood of Kingston as a teenager. Always deeply in love with music, Marley endured several years of false starts as a solo artist before finding success on the Jamaican charts with his first band, The Wailing Wailers, in 1964, but when financial success did not follow, the band soon fell apart.
*
After living in the US for a brief period in 1966, Marley reunited with former bandmates PETER TOSH and BUNNY WAILER to form the Wailers; by 1972, they were on their way to international success, with their first record deal. Though Tosh and Wailer would eventually leave the group, Bob Marley and the Wailers performed up until Marley succumbed to cancer in 1981. üáØüá≤üáØüá≤üáØüá≤üáØüá≤üáØüá≤
*
Beyond countless hits that still resonate and enthrall audiences today, almost 40 years after his death, Marley is often credited with bringing reggae music into the global mainstream, and for being the first "Third World" rock star. But far beyond that, his Rastafarian faith and messages of freedom and peace made him a powerful political force not just in Jamaica, but throughout the African diaspora...so powerful, in fact, that Marley, his wife Rita, and their manager were all shot in an assassination attempt in 1976.
‚úäüèø‚úäüèæ‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèº
*
While Marley was inducted posthumously into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1994, he did receive the Jamaican Order of Merit and the United Nations Medal of Peace from the United Nations before his death. The Marley family has continued the family tradition of music in the decades since, and The Marley Foundation works to honor his memory through good works.

On this day in 2012, TRAYVON MARTIN was walking back to a family member's house in Sanford, Florida after grabbing snacks from a local store. He never made it home, because he was shot to death by George Zimmerman, an armed neighborhood watchman who followed the teenager, despite 911 orders telling him not to. Trayvon was unarmed, yet Zimmerman was later acquitted, under the Gunshine State's "Stand Your Ground" laws. This injustice led to the creation of #BlackLivesMatter, the brainchild of radical activists ALICIA GARZA, PATRISSE CULLORS, and OPAL TOMETI.
‚Äî
In the words of the @blklivesmatter team: "(Black Lives Matter) is now a member-led global network of more than 40 chapters. Our members organize and build local power to intervene in violence inflicted on Black communities by the state and vigilantes.

Black Lives Matter is an ideological and political intervention in a world where Black lives are systematically and intentionally targeted for demise. It is an affirmation of Black folks‚Äô humanity, our contributions to this society, and our resilience in the face of deadly oppression.

As organizers who work with everyday people, BLM members see and understand significant gaps in movement spaces and leadership. Black liberation movements in this country have created room, space, and leadership mostly for Black heterosexual, cisgender men‚Äîleaving women, queer and transgender people, and others either out of the movement or in the background to move the work forward with little or no recognition. As a network, we have always recognized the need to center the leadership of women and queer and trans people. To maximize our movement muscle, and to be intentional about not replicating harmful practices that excluded so many in past movements for liberation, we made a commitment to placing those at the margins closer to the center."
‚úäüèø‚úäüèæ‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèº Rest in power, Trayvon.
‚Äî

Archbishop Emeritus DESMOND MPILO TUTU was born in South Africa in 1931, and came of age during the brutal ascension and adoption of APARTHEID, a system of institutionalized racial segregation and discrimination that ruled the nation between 1948 and 1991. As he ascended through the ranks of the Anglican Church, both at home and in England, Tutu used his religious clout to fight apartheid, becoming the first black man to hold increasingly significant leadership positions within the church. As his prominence reached an international scale, the South African government hesitated to make a martyr out of him, so he was able to avoid severe state-sanctioned retribution in ways that non-clergy activists like Nelson Mandela were not.
‚Äî

As the so-called "moral conscience of South Africa," Tutu has long supported reconciliation and forgiveness rather than retribution and resentment, and received criticism for being too quick to believe that unity was possible among the races. Though officially retired, Tutu has continued to fight for human rights, speaking out against everything from the war in Iraq to the occupation in Palestine; and calling for a united global response to the AIDS epidemic and climate change. He equates homophobia and limitations on LGBTQ rights with racism and apartheid, and is dismissive of those in the church who say otherwise.
‚Äî

Tutu's wife LEAH is also an educator and activist. The couple married in 1955, had four children, and are still together today.
‚Äî

After her husband was assassinated by a white supremacist in 1963, MYRLIE EVERS-WILLIAMS fought for 30 years to see his killer brought to justice, and became a civil rights hero in her own right.
‚Äî
Born and raised in Mississippi by her schoolteacher grandmother, Evers-Williams is quick to insist that the things she did not have growing up taught her exactly what kind of life she wanted to make for herself. She met her first husband, Medgar, while studying at Alcorn A&M College‚Äìone of the only schools in Mississippi that accepted black students at the time. As Medgar Evers became a rising star in the local NAACP, she fought for civil rights alongside him.
‚Äî
After her husband's death in 1963, Evers-Williams fought tirelessly for justice for his murderer, who was not convicted until the 1990s. At the same time, she and her children moved to California to forge a new, hopefully safer life. She worked in advertising and community affairs during the 70s, and also gave speeches for the NAACP. She wrote a book chronicling Medgar's life, and even ran (unsuccessfully) for Congress in 1970.
‚Äî
After decades of serving her new hometown of Los Angeles, she was appointed to the city's board of Public Works in 1987. As a member of the NAACP board during a time of turmoil, she opted to run for chair in 1995, and won. During her three-year tenure she turned the organization's reputation and financials around, and stepped down in 1998. She later went on to establish the Medgar Evers Institute, in Mississippi.
‚Äî
In recent years, Evers-Williams, twice a widow, continues to speak out about racial inequality, and write books about her own journey and that of her first husband. She's received at least 7 honorary doctorates over the years, been honored as Ms. Magazine's Woman of the Year, and received the National Freedom Award in 2009.
‚Äî
After Barack Obama was re-elected in 2012, Evers-Williams became the first woman of any race, and the first non-clergy, to deliver an invocation at a presidential inauguration.

SOJOURNER TRUTH (circa 1797-1883) was a legend in the abolitionist and suffrage movements of the 1800s. Born a slave named Isabella Baumfree in New York, Truth escaped to freedom with her infant daughter in 1826, later suing her former owner for her five-year-old son's freedom. Remarkably, she won, in one of the first legal victories for a black person suing a white one. ‚úäüèø‚úäüèæ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèº
Truth devoted her life to abolishing slavery, and was considered a radical even within those circles, because she also advocated for women's rights and chastised those who focused solely on the rights of black men. By 1850, she was giving speeches to audiences increasingly open to the fight against slavery, including her iconic "Ain't I a Woman" speech in Akron, Ohio. Her focus went beyond abolition after the Emancipation Proclamation, as she focused on prison reform, desegregation, and eliminating capital punishment.  She continued to give speeches until her age kept her home. Truth died in her chosen home of Michigan in 1883, but her work, her words, and her name live on.

As an activist and author, as a convicted murder who escaped from a life sentence, ASSATA SHAKUR remains a controversial figure in modern American history, despite over three decades living in exile in Cuba. ‚úäüèø‚úäüèæ‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèº
Born in Queens, raised in both NYC and North Carolina, Shakur (ne√© JoAnne Byron) found her start in activism while in community college, briefly working with the Black Panthers for less than a year in 1970, before aligning with the Black Liberation Army. A vocal protestor of the Vietnam War, and a champion of racial equality and equity, Shakur was often a focus of police investigation and frequent surveillance. In May 1973, a supposedly routine traffic stop ended with the death of Shakur's friend and a NJ state trooper, and Shakur's arrest.
üö®üö®üö®üö®üö®
Between 1973 and 1977, Shakur was indicted ten times, leading to seven trials for various crimes. Three charges were dismissed, and she was acquitted of three others. However, despite numerous medical experts claiming that she couldn't have possibly shot and killed anyone with her own bullet wounds, Shakur was convicted of NJ State Trooper Werner Foerster's murder in the spring of 1977. By November 1979, Shakur escaped, with the help of the BLA, ultimately resurfacing in Cuba, where she's been living in exile ever since.
üá®üá∫üá®üá∫üá®üá∫üá®üá∫üá®üá∫
Today, Shakur remains on the FBI's most wanted list, and Donald Trump has rescinded Obama's "Cuban Thaw" policies, specifically citing his intention to get Shakur back stateside, referring to her as "the cop‚Äìkiller Joanne Chesimard." Shakur has since written two books: Assata: An Autobiography (1987), and Still Black, Still Strong (1993); despite her exile, her influence can be seen in music, art, and activism today.

Hank Aaron grew from humble beginnings in Mobile, Alabama, passed through the sandlots with brief stops in the Negro Leagues and the minor leagues before he settled in with the Milwaukee Braves in 1954, and ultimately became one of baseball‚Äôs most iconic figures. ‚öæÔ∏è‚öæÔ∏è‚öæÔ∏è‚öæÔ∏è‚öæÔ∏è
It wasn‚Äôt until 1973 that Aaron was thrust into the national spotlight as he neared the finish of a successful assault on one of sport‚Äôs most cherished records- Babe Ruth‚Äôs mark of 714 home runs. Letters poured into the Braves offices, as many as 3,000 a day for Aaron. Some wrote to congratulate him, but many others were appalled that a black man should break baseball's most sacred record. Death threats were a part of the mix.
‚öæÔ∏è‚öæÔ∏è‚öæÔ∏è‚öæÔ∏è‚öæÔ∏è
After seizing the record in April 1974, Aaron was baseball‚Äôs all-time home run king for over three decades, until his record of 755 home runs was passed in 2007.

TIDYE PICKETT and LOUISE STOKES were the first two African-American women to qualify to represent the USA in the Olympics. üèÉüèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüèÉüèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüèÉüèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüèÉüèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüèÉüèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
Both qualified a relay runners for the 1932 Olympiad; however, only white athletes were allowed to participate, despite having lesser speeds.  Not only were Pickett and Stokes not allowed to compete, but they were forced to eat and live separately from their fellow Olympians who were white. Some of the athletes, like the legendary Babe Didrickson, were openly hostile toward the women. üñïüèøüñïüèæüñïüèæüñïüèº
Pickett qualified for the Olympics again in 1936, in the 80m hurdles.  This time she was allowed to compete, but her journey to Olympic gold was thwarted after she broke her foot on a hurdle.  Meanwhile, Stokes again qualified to run in the 4x100m relay; but just as in 1932, she was replaced by a white runner in the finals of the event. üíîüíîüíîüíîüíî
At the time, track and field was a sports genre that women of all races were discouraged from, due to patriarchal concerns about any possible impact on the athletes' ability to become pregnant. ü§îü§®ü§îü§®ü§î
Because of their talent and their will to compete and endure racial bigotry, African American athletes can freely compete and represent their country in the Olympics and beyond. ‚úäüèº‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèø

Have you heard about THE ORANGEBURG MASSACRE?
‚ùì‚Åá‚ùì‚Åá‚ùì
Fifty years ago today, on the night of February 8, 1968, nine South Carolina Highway Patrolmen fired into a crowd of black students protesting on the campus of South Carolina State University. Three students were killed; twenty-eight were injured. Almost every man was hit in the back.
üíîüíîüíîüíîüíî
The shootings were the culmination of lengthy protests against segregation and racial discrimination in Orangeburg, especially the ‚Äúwhite only‚Äù policy of a local bowling alley. For the first time ever, the feds brought charges against the state patrolmen for using excessive force at a campus protest. The officers claimed that they felt they were in danger, and that protesters had shot at the officers first. üôÑüôÑüôÑüôÑüôÑ
All nine defendants were acquitted, despite THIRTY SIX witnesses swearing that they did not hear gunfire, and despite the fact that all of the students were found to be unarmed.
üî∂üî∏üî∂üî∏üî∂
Unlike so many other protests and martyrs of the Civil Rights Movement, few people know the names Samuel Hammond, Henry Smith, and Delano Middleton. Historians have‚Äîwith only a few exceptions‚Äîignored the Orangeburg tragedy in discussion of student protests, focusing instead on Berkeley and Columbia, or Kent State and Jackson State.
‚úäüèø‚úäüèæ‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèº

"In the name of Jesus, this flag has to come down. You come against me with hatred and oppression and violence. I come against you in the name of God. This flag comes down today." ~@bree.newsome
‚úäüèº‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèø
BREE NEWSOME was arrested on June 27, 2015, after she removed the Confederate flag flying in front of South Carolina State house in Columbia, SC. A Charlotte native and lifelong activist, her act of civil disobedience came just ten days after Dylann Roof, a white supremacist hoping to "start a race war," massacred 9 people at the historic Emanuel AME church.
‚úäüèº‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèø
Newsome, just 30 at the time, "felt an overwhelming call" to remove the flag, and endured climbing training on light posts and flag poles before embarking on her early-morning mission, with fellow activist James Tyson waiting for her down below, and a team of lookouts pretending to be joggers.
‚úäüèº‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèø
The flag was raised again within an hour of her taking it down, but on July 10th, just 13 days after Newsome's unforgettable ascent, the symbol of slavery and white supremacy was taken down for good, by order of then-governor Nikki Haley. As Newsome told @voxdotcom in 2017, "I honestly believe that the flag would still be up today had we not put that additional pressure on the state."
‚úäüèø‚úäüèæ‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèº
Thank you, BREE NEWSOME!

In 1963, NAACP Field Secretary MEDGAR EVERS (1925-1963) was assassinated in front of his Mississippi home, his wife and children waiting for him inside. Three trials and 30+ years later, his murderer was finally convicted and sent to prison. The circus of those trials often overshadow Evers‚Äô meaningful civil rights work in Mississippi, where Evers spent a decade working against segregation in schools and places of business. He led demonstrations, recruited for the NAACP, and led boycotts of companies that still embraced segregation.
‚úäüèø‚úäüèæ‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèº
Though he wasn‚Äôt a nationally known activist or celebrity, Evers was very well-known in Mississippi, especially after demanding further investigation into the lynching of Emmett Till in 1955. He was constantly threatened by those who would uphold white supremacy‚Äìand his home was firebombed just weeks before he was murdered.
‚úäüèº‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèø
His college sweetheart and widow, Myrlie, took his work on as her own after Evers‚Äô death. She became a prominent activist in her own right‚Ä¶but we‚Äôll tell you more about Myrlie Evers on another day.

Before he became the "Father of Black History," Carter Godwin Woodson (1875-1950) was born to former slaves. After spending much of his childhood working to help his family, he did not start high school until age 20, graduating two years later.
‚úäüèº‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèø
In 1912, Dr. Woodson became the second African-American to earn a doctorate from @harvard. As one of the first scholars of African-American history, he insisted that knowing what their forebears had accomplished was essential to future black generations being inspired to succeed. Determined to spread that much-needed knowledge, Goodson released the first volume of THE JOURNAL OF NEGRO HISTORY on January 1, 1916. The quarterly publication still exists today, now known as The Journal of African American History.
‚úäüèº‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèø
In 1926, Woodson founded NEGRO HISTORY WEEK, choosing the second week of February because it included both Frederick Douglass' and Abraham Lincoln's birthdays. 20 years after his death in 1950, black students and faculty at @kentstate celebrated the first Black History Month. 50 years after Negro History Week was created, President Gerald Ford officially recognized it, in 1976.
‚úäüèº‚úäüèΩ‚úäüèæ‚úäüèø

*

"On Oct. 4, 1924, Nellie Tayloe Ross watched as her husband‚Äôs coffin was lowered into the ground. William B. Ross had been governor of Wyoming for only a year and 10 months. 
That afternoon, back at the governor‚Äôs mansion, the chairman of the state Democratic Committee knocked on the door and asked a delicate question: Would Mrs. Ross consider running for governor herself? The election was a month away.

Over the next few days, as she and her brother went around and around on the question of whether she should run. Not only was she shocked and sorrowful over her husband‚Äôs sudden death, she was also ambitious. And if she did run, they both understood, ambition was a quality she‚Äôd have to disguise. It just wasn‚Äôt seemly for a woman to look ambitious." On January 5, 1925, Nellie Tayloe Ross became the first woman governor of any US state. She went on to be the first woman director of the US Mint.
